noteParagraph.text: Processes involving only a single technical art, e.g. drying, coating, for which provision exists elsewhere are classified in the relevant class for that art.

titlePart.text: SELECTION OF MATERIALS FOR THEIR CONDUCTIVE, INSULATING, OR DIELECTRIC PROPERTIES
Conductors or conductive bodies characterised by the conductive materials
mainly consisting of metals or alloys
mainly consisting of carbon-silicon compounds, carbon, or silicon
mainly consisting of other non-metallic substances
Conductive material dispersed in non-conductive inorganic material
the conductive material comprising metals or alloys
the conductive material comprising carbon-silicon compounds, carbon, or silicon
Conductive material dispersed in non-conductive organic material
the conductive material comprising metals or alloys
the conductive material comprising carbon-silicon compounds, carbon, or silicon
Insulators or insulating bodies characterised by the insulating materials
Selection of materials for their insulating or dielectric properties
titlePart.entryReference: selection of piezo-electric or electrostrictive materials

titlePart.text: containing halogen in the molecules, e.g. halogenated oils
condensation products of phenols with aldehydes or ketones
condensation products of aldehydes with amines or amides
Non-insulated conductors or conductive bodies characterised by their form
Single bars, rods, wires, or strips
Several wires or the like stranded in the form of a rope
stranded around a space, insulating material, or dissimilar conducting material
comprising conductive layers or films on insulating-supports
titlePart.entryReference: insulating-layers or insulating-films on metal bodies

titlePart.text: Comprising conductive material in insulating or poorly conductive material, e.g. conductive rubber
Insulated conductors or cables characterised by their form
Flexible cables, conductors, or cords, e.g. trailing cables
Extensible conductors or cables, e.g. self-coiling cords
titlePart.entryReference: installations using extensible carrier for the cable

titlePart.text: Contact cables, i.e. having conductors which may be brought into contact by distortion of the cable

titlePart.entryReference: installations of cables supported on or from floats

titlePart.text: Other protection against mechanical force or pressure
Metal wires or tapes, e.g. made of steel
Devices affording localised protection against mechanical force or pressure
Reduction of losses in sheaths or armouring
Protection, e.g. against corrosion, chemical attack, influence of weather
with arrangements for reducing conductor losses when carrying ac, e.g. due to skin effect
with arrangements for indicating defects, e.g. breaks, leaks
with arrangements for heat dissipation, shielding, or conduction
with screens or conductive layers, e.g. for avoiding large potential gradients
Cables for use in conduits under fluid pressure
Cables with twisted pairs or quads
titlePart.entryReference: transposing, crossing, or twisting at joints

titlePart.text: with pairs or quads mutually positioned to reduce cross-talk
titlePart.entryReference: balancing by making use of additional capacitors or coils

titlePart.text: with means for reducing effects of electromagnetic or electrostatic disturbances, e.g. screen
Screens specially adapted for reducing cross-talk
Screens specially adapted for reducing interference from external sources
Arrangements for exhibiting specific transmission characteristics
Continuously inductively loaded cables, e.g. Krarup cables
Cables, e.g. submarine cable, with coils or other devices incorporated during cable manufacture
Analogous cables having more than one inner conductor within a common outer conductor
titlePart.entryReference: suitable for handling frequencies considerably beyond the audio range

titlePart.text: Cables having a multiplicity of coaxial lines
Superconductive or hyperconductive cables or transmission lines
Apparatus or processes specially adapted for manufacturing conductors or cables
Mutually-positioning pairs or quads to reduce cross-talk
by passing through, or dipping in, a liquid bath
Applying discontinuous insulation, e.g. discs, beads
by winding, braiding, or longitudinal lapping
Applying continuous inductive loading, e.g. Krarup loading
Apparatus or processes for salvaging material from cables
Insulators or insulating bodies characterised by their form
Fastening of insulator to support, to conductor, or to adjoining insulator

titlePart.entryReference: devices for relieving mechanical tension of electric lines or cables

titlePart.text: Fastening of insulators to support, to conductor, or to adjoining insulator
for very heavy conductors, e.g. bus-bars, rails
Insulators apertured for fixing by nail, screw, wire, or bar, e.g. diabolo, bobbin
Single insulators consisting of two or more dissimilar insulating bodies
Insulators having evacuated or gas-filled spaces
Means for obtaining improved distribution of voltage
Structural association of insulators with corona rings
Means for providing an external arc-discharge path
over chains or other serially-arranged insulators
with surfaces specially treated for preserving insulating properties, e.g. for protection against moisture, dirt, etc.
Tubes, sleeves, beads, or bobbins through which the conductor passes
titlePart.entryReference: protective tubings for the installation of lines or cables in buildings

titlePart.text: Insulating-layers or insulating-films on metal bodies
titlePart.entryReference: conductive layers or films on insulating bodies

titlePart.text: with conductive admixtures, inserts, or layers
titlePart.entryReference: conductive bodies comprising conductive material dispersed in insulating material

titlePart.text: Joining insulating bodies together, e.g. by bonding
Apparatus or processes specially adapted for manufacturing insulators or insulating bodies
Treating the surfaces, e.g. applying coatings
